text:
In the unit, we are using factors and multiples to explore and represent some properties of the multiplicative structure of numbers and solve problems. At the end of this investigation, ask yourself:

How can you express the multiplicative patterns and relationships of whole numbers with words, numeric expressions, and algebraic expressions?

Students might respond with understandings such as the following:

  • Exponents shorten the string of numbers being multiplied by combining the same factors into shorter notation. For example, 3 × 3 × 3 × 3 × 3 = 35.
  • Numbers can be broken down (decomposed) into factor strings. When the strings start to repeat factors, exponents help to write the expression.
  • Prime factorization is a way to show an equivalent expression for a number.
  • Any number can be written as a product of primes.
  • The factorization can show the structure of a number as a product of primes.
  • Prime factorizations can be used to find common factors, GCF, common multiples, and LCM.
  • The multiplicative structure of number may show up in special numbers such as prime, composite, or square numbers.
